Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I stood in the hallway, laundry basket in hand, feeling the weight of my wife’s reminder echoing in my mind: “Please don’t forget to do the laundry today. We need clean clothes for the kids’ activities tomorrow.” I promised her I’d take care of it, and I could already picture the disappointment on her face if I let it slip again. But I also had my mail-in ballot in the other hand, ready to drop it off at the polling station on my way to the laundry room. 

At the polling station, a poll worker inspected my envelope and frowned. “I’m sorry, but your signature smudged. Could you please re-sign it so your vote counts?” I hesitated, glancing at the clock. If I took too long, I’d miss my window to get the laundry done before the kids got home. But the poll worker’s expectant look reminded me how important it was to follow every instruction to ensure my vote wasn’t rejected. 

I felt torn, caught between my promise to my wife and my duty as a voter, both demanding my attention at the same moment. My heart pounded as I weighed which responsibility to honor first.
